questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Song of Solomon 1:1-16 aloud, paying attention to the bride's description and the beloved's response.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'I am very dark, but lovely' (v.5)
Pay attention to the contrast between the bride's darkness and the beloved's comparison to a mare among Pharaoh's chariots (v.16)
The emotional tone shifts from longing to confidence in the beloved's response

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is longing, WHAT they are seeking, WHERE this longing occurs, and WHY they are drawn to the beloved.
tips: The bride (the church) is longing for the beloved (Christ) in verses 1-2
The setting is intimate (the king's chambers) and the vineyard (the church's spiritual life)
The bride's darkness symbolizes sin and the need for the beloved's love

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the bride's declaration of being dark but lovely (v.5), the beloved's response about the flock (v.10), or the comparison to a mare among Pharaoh's chariots (v.16)?
tips: The bride's declaration 'I am very dark, but lovely' (v.5) resonates because it acknowledges sin while affirming God's love
The beloved's instruction to 'follow the tracks of the flock' (v.10) shows active pursuit and trust in the beloved's guidance
The comparison to a mare among Pharaoh's chariots (v.16) powerfully illustrates the beloved's strength and sovereignty

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to married couples and Israel about love and the church's longing for Christ?
tips: Solomon emphasizes that the church's longing for Christ is beautiful and powerful, even in the midst of sin (darkness)
He shows that Christ is the ultimate source of love and provision (better than wine), calling the church to follow Him
This passage foreshadows the church's identity as the bride of Christ who is loved despite imperfections

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'dark', the cultural context of tents of Kedar, or the comparison to Pharaoh's chariots?
tips: The term 'dark' in v.5 refers to the bride's sinfulness and the absence of light, but it is contrasted with the beloved's love
Tents of Kedar (v.5) are from the desert and symbolize the bride's beauty despite being from a harsh environment
Pharaoh's chariots (v.16) represent the power of Egypt (sin) and the beloved's strength in the midst of it

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Like the bride who is dark but lovely, how can you let Christ's love transform your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you feel 'dark' (sinful) and ask Christ to be your light
Practice 'following the tracks of the flock' by seeking Christ's guidance in your daily decisions
Share your longing for Christ with a friend this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for His love that sees you as lovely despite your darkness. Ask for strength to follow the beloved's lead.
tips: Thank God for the bride's declaration that He is better than wine (v.2)
Pray for the courage to be 'dark' (sinful) yet still be loved by Christ
Ask for the grace to follow the tracks of the flock (v.10) in your daily life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Song of Solomon 2:1-17 aloud, paying attention to the imagery and the repeated phrase 'the beloved' in verses 5-6.
tips: Notice the comparison of the speaker to a lily and a rose (v.1-2)
Pay attention to the phrase 'sick with love' (v.4) which shows deep emotion
The repeated 'he' in verses 5-6 emphasizes the beloved's coming

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being described (the speaker), WHAT the beloved is doing (visiting), WHERE the visit takes place (the speaker's home), and WHY the speaker is excited (the beloved's arrival signaling spring).
tips: The speaker is a young woman in love with a young man (the beloved)
The beloved is coming from a distance (leaping over mountains)
The speaker's home is the setting where the beloved stands behind the wall

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the lily among thorns (v.2), the beloved's leap over mountains (v.5), or the call to 'arise and come away' (v.5).
tips: The lily among thorns (v.2) shows the speaker's love is beautiful even in a difficult world
The beloved leaping over mountains (v.5) is a powerful image of Christ's coming to rescue us from spiritual death
The call to 'arise and come away' (v.5) is a joyful invitation to leave winter and enter spring

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to married couples/Israel about the nature of love and the coming of the Messiah?
tips: Solomon uses the beloved as a metaphor for Christ, who comes to save us from spiritual winter
The 'banner of love' (v.3) shows that Christ's love is our protection and strength
This passage points to the believer's need for the Messiah to bring spring (new life) and overcome the 'thorns' of sin

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The use of 'sick with love' (v.4), the 'leaping over mountains' (v.5), or the 'flowers appear' (v.5).
tips: 'Sick with love' (v.4) means the speaker is emotionally overwhelmed by love, not a physical illness
The 'leaping over mountains' (v.5) is a metaphor for Christ's coming to rescue us from spiritual death
The 'flowers appear' (v.5) symbolizes the resurrection and new creation

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: The beloved's call to 'arise and come away' (v.5) is a command to leave the past and enter new life. What area of your life needs this spring invitation this week?
tips: Identify one 'winter' in your life (e.g., broken relationships, depression, spiritual dryness)
Pray for the beloved (Christ) to come and refresh you with the 'apples' of His grace
Practice 'arising' by taking one step toward new life this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray that the beloved (Christ) will come and refresh you with His love, just as He did for the speaker in this passage.
tips: Thank God for the spring of new life He brings through Christ
Ask for courage to 'arise' and leave the winter of your life
Pray that Christ will 'leap over mountains' to reach you when you feel distant

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Song of Solomon 3:1-13 aloud, focusing on the night seeking and the city search.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'I sought him' (v.1, 3) showing persistence
Pay attention to the emotional tone of longing and then joy when found (v.4-5)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the speaker) does WHAT (seeks and finds), WHERE (on the bed at night and then in the city), and WHY (to find the beloved).
tips: The speaker seeks the beloved on the bed at night (v.1) and then goes through the city (v.2-3) to find him
The watchmen find the speaker and then the beloved is found (v.4-5)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the night seeking (v.1), the city search (v.2-3), or the immediate finding (v.4-5)?
tips: The night seeking: 'On my bed by night I sought him' shows deep longing and intimacy
The city search: 'I will rise now and go about the city' shows active pursuit
The immediate finding: 'Scarcely had I passed them when I found him' shows divine timing and presence

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to married couples and Israel about the pursuit of the beloved?
tips: Solomon emphasizes that true love requires active pursuit and trust, as the beloved is found in the midst of the city (v.4-5)
This passage also points to Christ as the beloved who is found by the church through the Holy Spirit (v.5)
The wedding carriage of Solomon (v.11) symbolizes Christ's coming and the church's role in His wedding

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The night seeking, the city search, or the identity of the beloved?
tips: The phrase 'my soul loves' (v.1) is a Hebrew term for deep affection, not just romantic love
The 'litter of Solomon' (v.11) is a royal carriage made from Lebanon wood, which is a symbol of Christ's authority and coming
The 'sixty mighty men' (v.11) refers to the church's role in Christ's triumph, not literal soldiers

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of seeking the beloved (Christ) in your life this week?
tips: Pray for the Holy Spirit to lead you to Christ (the beloved) in the midst of your daily activities
Spend time in quiet seeking (like the speaker on the bed) before going about your day
Trust that Christ will be found when you pursue Him (like the speaker finding the beloved in the city)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the pursuit of Christ and ask for the courage to seek Him.
tips: Thank God that He is the beloved who is always found by those who seek Him
Ask for the Holy Spirit to help you pursue Christ in the city of your life
Pray for the strength to be found by Christ and to hold Him (like the speaker holding the beloved)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Song of Solomon 4:1-16 aloud, paying attention to the poetic descriptions of the bride's beauty and the locked garden.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'behold' (v.1, 2) emphasizing the bride's beauty
Pay attention to the imagery of the bride's eyes as doves behind her veil (v.1) and hair like goats (v.2)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is praised, WHAT is described (the bride's beauty), WHERE this takes place (the garden), and WHY (to celebrate the bride's perfection).
tips: Include the bride's description as having no flaw (v.7)
Note the locked garden (v.12) as a symbol of the bride's purity
Describe the call for the winds to spread the fragrance (v.15-16)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the bride's eyes as doves behind her veil (v.1), the hair like goats leaping down Gilead (v.2), or the locked garden (v.12)?
tips: The image of the bride's eyes as doves behind her veil (v.1) evokes peace and grace
The hair like goats leaping down Gilead (v.2) shows strength and vitality
The locked garden (v.12) symbolizes the bride's preciousness and the need for the Spirit's wind to release her fragrance

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to married couples and Israel about the beauty of their bride?
tips: The bride is described without flaw, reflecting the church's completeness in Christ
The locked garden represents the church as a sealed community that only the Spirit can open
The call for the winds to spread the fragrance points to the church's mission to the world

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The imagery of the bride's beauty, the meaning of the locked garden, and the role of the winds?
tips: The phrase 'goats leaping down Gilead' (v.2) uses a specific cultural image of strength and beauty in the mountains
The locked garden (v.12) is a metaphor for the church that is sealed by God's presence, not accessible to the world
The winds (v.15-16) represent the Holy Spirit's work to release the church's fragrance to the world

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you embody the bride's beauty without flaw this week? Focus on the area where you feel imperfect but trust Christ's righteousness.
tips: Pray for the Holy Spirit to open your heart to the 'winds' that will release your fragrance
Identify one area where you need to be 'the bride' without flaw, trusting Christ's work
Practice being 'the locked garden'â€”a place of purity that only Christ can open

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the beauty of His bride, the church, and ask for the Spirit's wind to release her fragrance.
tips: Thank God for the church being without flaw through Christ's righteousness
Pray for the Spirit to open the locked garden of your heart
Ask God to send the winds of His Spirit to spread the fragrance of Christ's love

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Song of Solomon 5:1-16 aloud, focusing on the emotional tension of the beloved knocking and the speaker's response.
tips: Notice the phrase 'A sound! My beloved is knocking' (v2) - the suddenness of the beloved's arrival
Pay attention to the repeated phrase 'my beloved' (appears 10 times) to emphasize the intimate relationship
Listen for the contrast between the speaker's physical actions (putting off garment) and emotional state (heart thrilled)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is waiting, WHAT happens when the beloved knocks, WHERE it occurs (the garden), and WHY the speaker is so eager to open the door.
tips: Include the speaker's initial state: 'I came to my garden, my sister, my bride' (v1)
Note the beloved's knock and the speaker's immediate response: rising to open (v5)
Highlight the speaker's regret: 'I opened, but my beloved had turned and gone' (v5)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the knock (v2), the speaker's hesitation (v4), or the beloved's beauty (v16).
tips: The phrase 'A sound! My beloved is knocking' (v2) captures the sudden, life-changing moment of divine presence
The line 'I had put off my garment; how could I put it on?' (v4) shows the speaker's urgency and the cost of opening the door
The description 'My beloved is radiant and ruddy, distinguished among ten thousand' (v16) emphasizes the unparalleled beauty of Christ

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to married couples and Israel about the nature of love and the relationship with God?
tips: Solomon uses the garden as a metaphor for the heart of the believer, where Christ knocks at the door
The passage shows that true love requires courage to open the door even when we are hesitant
The beloved's beauty (v16) points to Christ's distinctiveness and holiness among all creation

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of the beloved knocking, the physical action of putting off a garment, and the phrase 'distinguished among ten thousand'.
tips: In ancient Israel, houses had gates that were opened by knocking (not a door), so the 'knocking' is a metaphor for Christ knocking at the heart of the believer (Revelation 3:20)
The phrase 'put off my garment' refers to removing the outer robe (a symbol of the old self) to prepare for the beloved's entrance, but the speaker realizes he cannot put it back on because he is too
'Distinguished among ten thousand' was a hyperbolic expression in ancient Near Eastern culture to emphasize the beloved's unparalleled beauty and holiness

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: When you feel the call of God (like the beloved knocking), what practical step can you take to open the door without hesitation?
tips: This week, when you experience a moment of divine calling (the knocking), pause and take a deep breath before opening your heart
Reflect on the cost: 'how could I put it on?' - are you ready to let go of what you've been holding onto?
Practice opening your heart by sharing a moment of trust with God, even if it's small

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He knocks at our hearts and ask for courage to open.
tips: Thank God for the love that knocks at your heart (Revelation 3:20) and for the beauty of Christ who is 'distinguished among ten thousand'
Pray for the strength to open the door when the beloved knocks, even when you feel hesitant
Ask God to help you recognize the call of the beloved (Christ) in your life and to respond with faith

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Song of Solomon 6:1-13 aloud, focusing on the imagery of the bride and the garden.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'I am my beloved's and my beloved is mine' (v. 3)
Pay attention to the emotional tone of the bride's beauty: 'beautiful as Tirzah, my love, lovely as Jerusalem, awesome as an army with banners' (v. 10)
The phrase 'turn away your eyes' (v. 4) conveys deep longing and vulnerability

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the bride), WHAT (her beauty and the garden), WHERE (the garden), and WHY (she is the only one chosen by the bridegroom).
tips: Include the bride's journey to the garden to gather lilies and spices (v. 1-2)
Note the comparison of her beauty to Tirzah and Jerusalem (v. 10)
Highlight that she is the 'only one' among many (v. 4)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the description of the bride's beauty (v. 10), the unique status of the bride as the only one (v. 4), or the imagery of the bride going to the garden (v. 1-2)?
tips: The phrase 'the only one' (v. 4) emphasizes the exclusivity of the bride's relationship with the bridegroom in a world of many
The imagery of the bride gathering lilies and spices (v. 1-2) shows her intimate connection with the garden and the bridegroom
The comparison of her beauty to Tirzah (a city of beauty) and Jerusalem (the city of God) (v. 10) is profound and resonates with the church's identity

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to married couples and Israel about the unique relationship between a husband and wife, and the church's place in Christ?
tips: Solomon emphasizes mutual belonging: 'I am my beloved's and my beloved is mine' (v. 3)
The bride is the only one chosen by the bridegroom (v. 4), reflecting how Christ is the only one for the church
The church is beautiful as Tirzah and Jerusalem, and awesome as an army with banners (v. 10), showing her strength and beauty in Christ

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The comparison of the bride to Tirzah and Jerusalem? The meaning of 'awesome as an army with banners'? The concept of the bride being the 'only one' in a world of many?
tips: 'Tirzah' was a city in ancient Israel known for its beauty and military strength, but here it symbolizes the bride's beauty and significance
'Awesome as an army with banners' likely refers to the bride's impact and authority, but in a positive sense (like the military strength of God's people)
The phrase 'the only one' (v. 4) in a context of many (60 queens and 80 concubines) emphasizes the bride's unique status in the bridegroom's heart

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of mutual belonging and the bride's unique beauty to your marriage or relationship this week?
tips: Set aside time to 'gather lilies' together (like the garden setting) to nurture your relationship
Recognize the unique value of your spouse (the bride) in your life, just as the bride is the only one for the bridegroom
Practice the mutual belonging: 'I am my beloved's and my beloved is mine' (v. 3) by actively showing love and commitment

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the unique love He has for His church and ask for the courage to be the bride in your life.
tips: Thank God that He is the bridegroom and the church is His only one (v. 4)
Pray for the strength to reflect Christ's beauty and the church's unique identity
Ask for the courage to be the bride (the church) in your marriage and community

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Song of Solomon 7:1-14 aloud, paying attention to the lover's description of the bride's beauty (verses 1-10) and the bride's response (verses 10-14).
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'how beautiful' in verses 4, 5, 7, 9, 10, and 12
Pay attention to the contrast between the lover's admiration and the bride's confident response
The phrase 'I am my beloved's, and his desire is for me' (verse 10) is a key declaration of mutual ownership

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize who (the lover and bride), what (the lover's description of the bride's beauty and the invitation to go into the fields), where (the fields and villages), and why (the mutual desire and love).
tips: The lover describes the bride's beauty in verses 1-10
The bride responds with mutual ownership in verse 10
They plan to go into the fields and lodge in villages together (verses 11-14)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the lover's vivid description of the bride's beauty (verses 1-10), the bride's declaration of mutual ownership (verse 10), or the invitation to go into the fields (verses 11-14).
tips: The description of the bride's feet in sandals (verse 1) shows deep appreciation for the bride's presence
The bride's declaration: 'I am my beloved's, and his desire is for me' (verse 10) is a powerful statement of commitment
The invitation to go out into the fields and lodge in villages (verse 11) represents active partnership and shared life

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to married couples and Israel about divine love through this passage?
tips: Solomon portrays the ideal marriage as one of mutual admiration and shared purpose
The passage foreshadows Christ's love for the church and the mission of the kingdom
The mutual desire and the plan to work together (verses 11-14) reflect unity in Christ

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The physical descriptions, the cultural context of the time, or the implications of the bride's ownership?
tips: The extensive physical descriptions (verses 1-10) are poetic and may be seen as objectifying; however, in context, they are expressions of deep admiration
The term 'noble daughter' (verse 1) reflects the cultural context of the bride as a high-status woman in ancient Israel
The bride's declaration of ownership ('I am my beloved's') is a strong statement of mutual commitment that may be challenging without the context of marriage

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice mutual admiration and shared purpose in your marriage or relationships this week?
tips: Take time to appreciate your partner's beauty (both physical and spiritual) as Solomon does
Plan a shared activity with your partner, like going into the fields (a metaphor for new experiences) together
Express your ownership and desire for your partner in a healthy way, like the bride's declaration

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the theme of mutual love and shared purpose in your marriage or relationship.
tips: Thank God for the beauty of your spouse and for the love that binds you together
Ask for the courage to express your desire and ownership in a way that builds trust
Pray that you and your spouse will work together in the 'fields' of life, serving God and others

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Song of Solomon 8:1-17 aloud, focusing on the phrases 'love is strong as death', 'many waters cannot quench love', and 'come quickly'.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'love is strong as death' (v.6) emphasizes its enduring nature
Pay attention to the emotional urgency in 'come quickly' (v.10)
The phrase 'jealousy is fierce as the grave' (v.6) shows the intensity of love

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is speaking, WHAT they are expressing about love, WHERE this love is found, and WHY it matters.
tips: Include the speaker's description of the beloved as a wall with breasts like towers (v.12)
Note the call to 'come quickly' (v.10) as a key action
Describe the unquenchable nature of love (v.7) as the central theme

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: Which part of the chapter resonated most with you? Consider: 'love is strong as death' (v.6), 'many waters cannot quench love' (v.7), or 'come quickly, my beloved' (v.10)?
tips: 'Love is strong as death' (v.6) illustrates that love is more powerful than death, which is a profound statement about enduring commitment
'Many waters cannot quench love' (v.7) shows that even in the most overwhelming circumstances, love remains
The call 'come quickly' (v.10) creates a sense of urgency and deep emotional connection

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to married couples and Israel about the nature of love and commitment?
tips: Solomon emphasizes that true love is unbreakable and eternal, even in the face of death or hardship
This passage shows that love is a seal (v.5) that identifies the couple as one in Christ
The 'love strong as death' concept foreshadows Christ's love for the Church, which is stronger than death

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of this chapter are challenging to interpret? Consider cultural context, unfamiliar terms, or theological concepts.
tips: The phrase 'seal upon your heart' (v.5) refers to a physical seal used in ancient Israel for identity and commitment, but in Christian context it symbolizes the Holy Spirit's indwelling
The comparison of love to 'death' (v.6) might be confusing because death is negative; here it means love is more powerful than death (i.e., it endures)
The term 'jealousy' (v.6) in this context is not about emotion but about the protective and intense nature of love, similar to the jealousy of God for His people

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of love being unquenchable (v.7) to a relationship this week?
tips: Identify a situation where you feel your love might be 'quenched' (e.g., conflict, distance) and practice active listening and patience
Pray for the strength to keep your love alive even when others are unfaithful or when facing hardship
Make a specific plan to 'come quickly' to the beloved (v.10) by reaching out to someone you love this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the theme of love that is strong as death and unquenchable.
tips: Thank God that His love for us is stronger than death (Romans 8:38-39)
Ask for the strength to love others as Christ loved us, even when it's difficult
Pray that you will be quick to respond to God's call (like the beloved in v.10) in your relationships
